title:
Thorough Analysis of $\pi^-p\rightarrow K^{*}\Sigma$ Reaction: Probing
  Nucleon Excited State and Constituent Scaling Laws
authors: Xiao-Yun Wang, Yuan Gao, Xiang Liu
abstract:
In this study, applying the effective Lagrangian approach, we investigate the
reaction $\pi^-p\rightarrow K^{*}\Sigma$ to explore the production of the
nucleon excited state $N^*(2080)$ and the constituent field scaling laws, also
known as the constituent counting rules. Specifically, we analyze two
scenarios, where the $J^P$ quantum numbers of $N^*(2080)$ are $3/2^-$ and
$1/2^-$. Our results show that the contribution from $s$-channel $N^*$ exchange
dominates the total cross section, surpassing those from $t$-channel $K^{(*)}$
exchange and $u$-channel $\Sigma$ exchange. Additionally, we present
predictions for the differential cross section of the $\pi^-p\rightarrow
K^{*}\Sigma$ process. Notably, in the large momentum transfer region ($\theta =
90^\circ$), the differential cross section in the $t$-distribution aligns with
the energy-dependent scaling formula predicted by the constituent counting
rule, specifically, $d\sigma/dt \sim 1/s^{8}$ for the $\pi^-p\rightarrow
K^{*}\Sigma$ reaction. Finally, we extend the 2-to-2 scattering process to the
2-to-3 Dalitz process and provide theoretical predictions for this scenario.
Our findings suggest that the cross section for the $\pi^-p \rightarrow
K^{*}\Sigma\rightarrow K^+\pi^-\Sigma^0$ process can reach several tens of $\mu
b$ near the threshold, making it highly favorable for experimental measurement.
However, the current scarcity of experimental data for the $\pi^-p\rightarrow
K^{*}\Sigma$ reaction at threshold energy limits our ability to precisely
determine the properties of the nucleon excited state $N^*$ and related
physical quantities. Therefore, additional experimental measurements of the
$\pi^-p \rightarrow K^{*}\Sigma$ reaction at threshold are strongly encouraged,
and correlation studies could be pursued at facilities such as J-PARC, AMBER,
and upcoming HIKE and HIAF meson beam experiments.
